Literature Review: The exploration of high-dimensional data bootstrap methods has garnered significant attention in recent years, driven by the increasing complexity and dimensionality of data across various scientific domains. This literature review delves into the advancements in high-dimensional bootstrap, focusing on the theoretical underpinnings, methodological innovations, and practical applications that have emerged from this vibrant area of research.High-dimensional central limit theorems (CLTs) for distributions of sample mean vectors over rectangles have been pivotal in understanding the behavior of high-dimensional data. Chernozhukov, Chetverikov, and Kato (2013) established foundational results in this area, demonstrating the validity of high-dimensional CLTs under certain regularity conditions. Their work has been instrumental in extending classical CLT results to high-dimensional settings, providing a theoretical basis for the application of bootstrap methods in high dimensions.Bootstrap consistency in high dimensions is another critical area of research. The empirical bootstrap, which resamples observations with replacement, and the multiplier bootstrap, which involves multiplying observations by random weights, have both been shown to achieve consistency under high-dimensional settings. Chernozhukov, Chetverikov, and Kato (2017) further explored these methods, highlighting the conditions under which bootstrap consistency can be achieved and the implications for high-dimensional inference.The application of high-dimensional bootstrap methods to construct simultaneous confidence sets for high-dimensional vector parameters has been a significant advancement. These methods allow for the simultaneous estimation of multiple parameters, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the data. Belloni, Chernozhukov, and Hansen (2014) contributed to this area by developing techniques for constructing confidence sets that account for the high-dimensional nature of the data, ensuring robust inference.Multiple hypothesis testing via step-down procedures has also benefited from high-dimensional bootstrap methods. These procedures adjust for the multiplicity of tests, controlling the family-wise error rate or the false discovery rate. Romano and Wolf (2005) introduced step-down methods that leverage bootstrap techniques to improve the power and accuracy of multiple testing in high-dimensional contexts.Post-selection inference, which addresses the challenge of making valid inferences after model selection, has seen innovative applications of high-dimensional bootstrap. Berk, Brown, and Zhao (2013) proposed methods that use bootstrap resampling to adjust for the selection bias, enabling valid inference post-selection in high-dimensional models.Intersection bounds for partially identified parameters represent another area where high-dimensional bootstrap methods have been applied. These bounds provide a range of plausible values for parameters that are not fully identified by the data. Chernozhukov, Lee, and Rosen (2013) developed bootstrap-based methods for estimating intersection bounds, offering a practical approach to inference in partially identified models.Inference on best policies in policy evaluation has also been enhanced by high-dimensional bootstrap methods. These methods allow for the assessment of the effectiveness of different policies in high-dimensional settings, taking into account the complexity of the data. Kitagawa and Tetenov (2018) utilized bootstrap techniques to evaluate policy interventions, providing insights into the optimal allocation of resources.Looking ahead, future research directions in high-dimensional bootstrap include the development of more efficient algorithms for bootstrap resampling in ultra-high dimensions and the exploration of bootstrap methods for non-standard data structures, such as network data or functional data. Additionally, there is a growing interest in integrating machine learning techniques with bootstrap methods to enhance the accuracy and interpretability of high-dimensional inference.In conclusion, the field of high-dimensional data bootstrap has made substantial progress, offering powerful tools for statistical inference in complex, high-dimensional settings. The theoretical advancements, methodological innovations, and practical applications reviewed here underscore the importance of continued research in this area, with the potential to significantly impact a wide range of scientific disciplines.
